description: From Middle English sproute, either from Middle English sprouten (“to sprout”) (see below); or from Middle Dutch sprute or Middle Low German sprûte (“sprout”). Doublet of spruit.

entries.meaning: A new growth on a plant, whether from seed or other parts.

examples: Oh my, how your sprouts have grown!
In our family we eat sprouts but once a year, on Christmas.

description: From Middle English sprouten, spruten, from Old English sprūtan, from Proto-West Germanic *spreutan, from Proto-Germanic *spreutaną.

verbs.description: sprout (third-person singular simple present sprouts, present participle sprouting, simple past and past participle sprouted)

entries.meaning: (horticulture, intransitive) To grow from seed; to germinate.
examples: The crocuses should be sprouting after 2 months, provided they're well tended.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to grow from a seed.
examples: I sprouted beans and radishes and put them in my salad.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To emerge from the ground as sprouts.
(figurative, intransitive) To emerge haphazardly from a surface.
examples: Whiskers sprouted from the old man's chin.

entries.meaning: (figurative, intransitive) To emerge or appear haphazardly
examples: A lot of coffee shops have sprouted up in this neighbourhood since the block of flats was put up.
